awd_titl_txt: Molecular Insights into the Oxidation of Atmospheric Mercury
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Theodore Dibble at the State University of New York (SUNY) College of Environmental Science and Forestry and Dr. Chuji Wang of Mississippi State University are investigating how atoms of mercury react in the atmosphere to form molecules that are readily transferred into ecosystems.  Atmospheric reactions of mercury are not well known.  Questions of where and when mercury enters ecosystems and how it is transported around the globe are of special interest. Mercury is toxic to people and wildlife. Mercury in the atmosphere is not present in harmful concentrations, but once mercury enters ecosystems it is concentrated in animal tissues to levels that are dangerous when eaten by other animals or humans. Dr. Dibble works with high school teachers to develop modules to teach kinetics based on mercury-containing chemistry. The broader impacts of this work include the first experimental determination of the products of atmospheric reactions of mercury-containing molecules, and the incorporation of the results of this research into atmospheric models of mercury chemistry and deposition.

This project focuses on mercury oxidation by atomic bromine (Br). Cavity ringdown spectroscopy (CRDS) is used to monitor the fate of the HgBr radical in reactions with atmospheric trace gases. CRDS experiments and computational chemistry are used to determine, for the first time, the rate constants for reactions of HgBr radicals with ozone, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and atmospherically abundant radicals (Y. radicals, where Y. = NO, NO2, HOO, ClO, BrO, and IO). Rate constants are determined as a function of temperature and pressure to span the full range of atmospheric conditions. Synergistic interactions between scientists doing field studies, modeling, and laboratory work accelerate progress towards understanding global mercury cycling.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Theodore S. Dibble of the SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry and Dr. Chuji Wang of Mississippi State University worked together to determine the reactions of mercury compounds in the atmosphere and how fast they will occur. Mercury is a toxin that particularly affects the brain and nervous system. Most non-industrial mercury exposure comes from eating fish, not from mercury in air. One might ask, then, why is it important to determine how mercury reacts in air? The answer is that the atmosphere acts as a highway to transport mercury from sites of emission to all over the globe. Mercury is emitted to the atmosphere mostly as individual atoms (Hg); however, mercury mostly enters ecosystems from the atmosphere when mercury atoms are bound to other atom (as mercury compounds). The interconversion of mercury from bare atoms to compounds strongly impacts when and where mercury leaves the atmosphere to enter ecosystems. Drs. Dibble and Wang worked with modelers to understand how atmospheric reactions of mercury influenced where and when mercury enters ecosystems.

When atoms of bromine (Br) reacts with Hg we get BrHg. We used experiments to determine how fast BrHg reacts with nitrogen dioxide (NO2). NO2 another radical, and is mostly made by combustion in human activities, but also by lightning. It is the most abundant radical in the atmosphere, and our previous calculations suggested it reacted with BrHg. We expected the rate of the reaction to depend on the total pressure (mostly nitrogen gas in our experiments). The rate of reaction did increase with total pressure, but when we extrapolated our results to zero pressure it appeared the reaction was still somewhat fast. After much head-scratching, we realized that two reactions were going on. One was occurring as we expected, to produce another mercury compound. But another reaction was occurring that did not get faster or slower as the temperature or pressure changed. This reaction seemed to make BrNO2 and bare mercury atoms. The competition between these two sets of reaction products will influence where and when mercury enters ecosystems.

A divide exists among scientists who model the behavior of mercury in the atmosphere. Some scientists suggest that ozone (O3) and the hydroxyl radical (OH) react with mercury to start the process of forming mercury compounds rather than, or in addition to, Br. Both Br and OH are neutral and both are radicals, meaning that they each have one unpaired electron. That unpaired electron makes them reactive. We used computers and commercial software for quantum chemistry to determine that HOHg (the product of OH reaction with Hg) behaves a lot like BrHg in reactions with NO2. However, we found that OH binds to Hg much more weakly than does Br. This means that HOHg, unlike BrHg, falls apart more rapidly than it is likely to react with another molecule in the atmosphere. That, in turn, suggested that OH can?t contribute much to starting the conversion of mercury from bare atoms to mercury compounds. We worked with scientists at Harvard to incorporate our results into a global model of the atmosphere. The model results confirmed that, on a global scale, OH does not add much to converting bare mercury atoms to mercury compounds.

A limit of the result above is that we had yet to realize that HOHg (and BrHg) can react with ozone. When we found this, we realized that this reaction somewhat prevents HOHg from falling apart and keeps mercury as a compound. So the scientists who thought that OH could react with mercury atoms were wrong about how (and how fast) that reaction occurs. We should acknowledge that they were right that both OH and ozone have a role in transforming mercury from bare atoms to mercury compounds. We again worked with Harvard scientists to do modeling, and now believe that OH can contribute a lot to making mercury compounds, if not as much as Br.

The ultimate goal of this research is to increase the reliability of efforts to reduce the human health impacts of environmental mercury. Four graduate students and eight undergraduate students worked on this project, receiving training in such topics as modern spectroscopy, computational chemistry, and professional skills.  We also carried out an array of outreach activities.
